title: Which major cryptocurrency will perform best between 27 May 2021 and 29 November 2021?
preds: Omicron variant in the news and looming US continuing resolution expiration plus US debt ceiling concerns following shortly thereafter.  More speculation might cause these values to rise, but I don't think the ratio of investments will shift very much.  slight increase in Bitcoin at expense of Cardano and XRP.
Ether maintains its lead with just a day to go, At this point, Ether seems to be likely winner.
One day left and Etherium holding strong followed closely in performance by Bitcoin.  No change to Cardano and Ripple.

Nassim Nicholas Taleb literally just posted this on his YouTube channel. It's short but there's a point where he talks about maximum drawdowns and how it's useful in assessing risk. I think it blends perfectly with cryptocurrency and trading where in this case, Bitcoin had more risk because it had larger drawdowns relative to Etherium. So in retrospect, Etherium was, in one sense, more likely to perform better than Bitcoin. LINK: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zLs6ggd3BPo
Final assessment:  ETH outperformed BTC during this period.

updating from previous forecast, BTC will need to gain a few % points to jump ahead of ETC, lately both have been moving in tandem, will need to see a significant jump for BTC to pull ahead on the last day.

While BTC and ETC have dropped considerably over the last three weeks, BTC dropped more.  Currently, over the designated period, BTC has increased by ~41% while ETH = ~67%.  Unless significant changes occur tomorrow, ETH will outperform BTC.  (Ada and XRP have not been competitive during this period.)

NOTE: BTH (up ~40%) is behind ETH (up ~47%), but with such high volatility, it's still possible for BTC to come out on top; meanwhile, ADA and XRP are both slightly negative, but given XRP's relatively lower correlation, it's not out of the game just yet. Still using a simulation to forecast the potential outcomes.

Stochastic simulation, but this time without the howling error in Etherium's variance.
XRP and Cardano have biggest opportunity to grow

Based on historical volatility, if we were only 2 days from resolution at current prices, my simulation would suggest 40% BTC, 0.5% ADA, 58% ETH, and 1.5% XRP. 
Given that we have almost a month of runway though, my simulation suggests 32% BTC, 11% ADA, 40% ETH, and 17% XRP. 
Seeing that some of the other forecasts, and the sudden shift since I started forecasting, I'm curious to know: have any of you used or built on my simulation?
I put it out there for others to use if they want, but I'm curious if you have feedback. 
For those making forecasts out of step with my simulation, would you be willing to make suggestions about why the forecast should be different? 
CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/major_crypto_relative_performance/crypto_relative.py
Stochastic simulation of four currencies for 27 days

With the approval for crypto currency to be traded via exchange-traded funds (ETF), I think the advantage for Bitcoin to outperform others gets a boost.  I tired to see if other crypto currencies were also approved.  Basically...if all cryptos were approved...then they should all benefit equally from the increase in demand and capital available to invest.  It took me a minute, but I think I found ETF that contain non-Bitcoin.  However, since that had to be searched out instead of being in the headlines about the new ETF, it will push Bitcoin slightly ahead and while rates of gain might equal out again, then a momentary advantage is still an advantage.

BTC and ETH catalysts (BTH ETF, BTC legal, ETH Altair upgrade–closer to proof-of-stake, ETH connection to Facebook Meta, and portfolio managers need to close the year with strong performing cryptos in their portfolio). In the absence of catalysts for ADA and XRP, BTC and ETH will retain their lead over the other two. Although BTC gain is greater than BTC currently, I see ETH being a stronger performer due to Metadata hype and the technological change towards proof-of-stake in their platform. I don’t want to throw ADA out of the running since it can store metadata as well.
Cardano is stable to slightly decreasing and doesn't appear likely to change much.  Same with Ripple.  Bitcoin confidence seems high and growing as does Ethereum.

Updating to balance more in the direction of some of the forecasters I follow while still leaning heavily on the Monte Carlo simulation results to inform my "outside view". See this comment for details on the simulation: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1349335

My ideal would be to use MCMC, but to get this out quickly, I put together a quick version of a Monte Carlo simulation that forces the cryptocurrencies to move according to how they are directionally correlated with respect to Bitcoin (e.g. in the real world, ETH moves the same direction as BTC about 80% of the time, so they must also share the same directionality 80% of the time in the simulation). The results surprised me.  My interpretation for the relative success of XRP compared to what I would have expected is that, in the event that the crypto market takes a dive, XRP is the least correlated with the others (although it is still highly correlated) and will likely fare the best. I suspect the crowd is underestimating the volatility of the cryptocurrency market.
SIMULATION RESULTS: { "BTC": 35.35%, "ADA": 13.5%, "ETH": 36.83%, "XRP": 14.32% }
CODE: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/major_crypto_relative_performance/crypto_relative.py
NOTE: I'm balancing these estimates against the estimates of the crowd in my forecast.

As of the start date of measurement (May 27, 2021), the value of the major cryptocurrencies in question stood at:
•	Bitcoin (CoinDesk): $38,717.77
•	Cardano (Ada) (CoinDesk): $1.66
•	Ethereum (CoinDesk): $2,774.54
•	XRP (Ripple) (CoinDesk): $0.979175
At the time of this writing (October 8, 2021), the values of these currencies and their percentage growth rates stood at:
•	Bitcoin (CoinDesk): $53,919.91 (39.26%)
•	Cardano (Ada) (CoinDesk): $2.27 (36.74%)
•	Ethereum (CoinDesk): $3,575.70 (28.87%)
•	XRP (Ripple) (CoinDesk): $1.06 (8.25%) When the success of growth is measured as a percentage starting at initial investment, then the two most obvious contenders for best performers become Bitcoin and Cardano. Bitcoin’s much higher value makes it far more likely to remain stable, with Cardano’s current value making more prone to both explosive growth and dramatic loss.
Trading Education predicts a “supply crunch” that could elevate the value of Bitcoin as high as $100,000, while they also remain bullish on Cardano as an “alternative to Ethereum” and have even shown accuracy in a previous prediction of Cardano reaching $2 (Trading Education, 2021). Being as Cardano has also reached the point of being the “third largest cryptocurrency by market cap, I judge it to have legitimate staying power in this debate (Trading Education, 2021). Despite this, the safe answer to the question of which cryptocurrency will perform best by November 29th remains Bitcoin, with its large market cap, brand recognition and proven track record. I would place my confidence level at 70% Bitcoin and 30% Cardano to be the best performer by November 29th, respectively. 
Reference:
Trading Education. (July 23, 2021). Which Cryptocurrencies Will Perform Best in 2021? https://trading-education.com/which-cryptocurrencies-will-perform-best-in-2021.

Which major cryptocurrency will perform best between 27 May 2021 and 29 November 2021? I believe this one to come down to Bitcoin and Cardano.This is an exceptionally if nye impossible area to predict due in no small part to the volatility of crypto. With that being said, I’m going to yield 60% prediction to Bitcoin and 40% to Cardano. Bitcoin, despite its own issues and volatility, is historically the more stable of the cryptos let alone the most valuable. While Ethereum is usually its more venerable opponent, Cardano has been sneaking up. With that said, as of today 10/9/2, Bitcoin sits at $54,620 a share. While it tumbled in the mid summer months to low 30’s from the high 50’s, it has seen a steady climb back to its current position and appears poised to keep climbing through the holidays. As for Cardano, it could quite possibly be the little engine that could. While it doesn’t have the value of Bitcoin, its percentage growth is nothing short of amazing. Between May and now it has seen a great deal of growth despite its own volatility. In mid May, it climbed from its 10cent initial value to $2.30 per share. As of mid-September, it sat at nearly $3.00 a share. It does appear to be presently losing steam and being outpaced by the crypto giant that is Bitcoin. However, whit it may not out pace Bitcoin, it does appear poised to outsell Etherium and the other cryptos like DOGECOIN.

This is a shot in the dark for me as I lack knowledge on crypto investing and think it to be more of an emotional buy than stocks are. Yes we can look back at the performance of a crypto just as we can with a stock for a company; however, crypto is not attached to a traded company nor is it aligned with a physical form of currency. This makes crypto tougher to speculate than an emerging tech company that is getting ready for IPO. I'm basing my prediction based on market caps. Bitcoin has the largest market cap, followed by Etherium, then Cardano, and finally Ripple. All that being said, I feel that one strong reddit group with a timely post could change the tide on performance for any of these currencies.

This one really threw me for a loop-- I know next to nothing about crypto. The one thing I do know is that governments don't like them because they are floating currencies untethered to any physical currency. So after doing some general background research, I began by investigating if any of these currencies drew any particular ire from any particular government that would impact its performance.  An interesting article came out today on this point: https://www.forbes.com/sites/billybambrough/2021/10/10/executive-order-bombshell-bitcoin-ethereum-cardano-bnb-xrp-solana-and-dogecoin-are-braced-for-a-massive-earthquake-amid-huge-price-pump/?sh=552a0c963130
 
So it seems both the West and China aim to crack down on crypto over the next several months, making it hard to tell why one might be targeted in particular. As a sort of financial populist counter-culture, crypto will probably do better in defiance of government crackdowns, as it has done all year-- more people will continue to buy shares. As the option with the highest brand recognition, Bitcoin is also most likely to benefit from new entries to the market (The opposite could be argued-- that this makes Bitcoin the biggest target to serve as an example to its smaller competitors, but this likely wouldn't happen by the end of November). So Bitcoin seems set to be at the top of the pack. I next compared 6 month performance of all 4 currencies, since that is the time period examined by CoinDesk closest to our dates. XRP is disqualified due to its -2% 6 months performance. It would take a miracle to catch up with the others. Bitcoin went down over the last 6 months, but is doing well again the past month. Ethereum and Cardano each do really well at 66% and 84% 6 month increases, respectively. However, Cardano has declined in the last month, weakening it more in our time period. Yet the longer term trend is on Cardano's side, with over a 2000%  increase over the past year compared to Ethereum's 850%.  Thus, although Cardano has settled down a bit, it should still have the largest change from May to November, since it has been increasing again toward its pre-drop rate from a month ago. Bitcoin should be carried through to second best despite its recent faltering the last 6 months, if for no other reason than name recognition. Ethereum is the most modestly performing of the 3.

Forbes reported the Top 10 Cryptocurrencies in October 2021 as: 1. BITCOIN(BTC), 2. Etherium (ETH), 3. Tether (USDT), 4. Cardano (ADA), 5. Binance Coin (BNB), 6. XRP (XRP), 7. Solana (SOL), 8. USD Coin (USDC), 9. Polkadot (DOT), and 10. Dogecoin (DOGE) (2021). US News reported, The Seven Contenders for the Best Crypto to Buy for 2021 as: 1. Bitcoin, 2. Bitcoin Cash, 3. Ethereum, 4. Cardano, 5. Dogecoin, 6. Binance Coin, and 7. Polkadot (2021). The CoinDesk Quarterly Review (Third Quarter 2021) assessed, “Q3 2021 was a welcome relief for the market after BTC and ETH hit all-time highs in early Q2 2021, only to come tumbling down. Both assets performed well from a price perspective, adding 25.0% and 31.8%, respectively. It felt as though the market was taking a breather, which revealed itself through lower volatility measures than in any other quarter this year, albeit with levels still far above established macro assets. On top of that, BTC proved mostly uncorrelated with gold, the S&P 500, bonds, and the US dollar, highlighting BTC could have a unique place in portfolios” (pg.2). The report also stated, “BTC and ETH outperformed traditional benchmarks, and ETH continued its winning streak against BTC, having outperformed the preeminent cryptocurrency by market capitalization in each 2021 quarter, hinting at the possibility that more money, institutional and retail, maybe entering the fold” (pg.4). Based on reporting and ratings, Etherium will perform best between 27 May 2021 and November 2021 (53%) (moderate-confidence), followed by BITCOIN (47%) (moderate-confidence).  Resources:

Forecasting prices of marketable securities (or equivalents, as in this case) is fraught with challenges – anyone who can reliably predict what will occur in the future for a given valuation needn’t work at anything else if they don’t want to. Rather than trying to predict price movements over the next two months, I will address a simpler question – do I believe it is likely that the current relative performances of the currencies in question will be disrupted over the next two months. In order to do so I look at two factors – what is the current standings in performance relative to the baseline in the question, and what information do I have that would allow me to factor in the likelihood of changes that would propel or depress one cryptocurrency versus another (as opposed to broad movements in the crypto market which would be shared across currencies). I assembled a table which shows the current gains associated with each and calculated a relative proportion of total gain across all four currencies. This is a starting point. Then I wanted to add in a factor regarding sensitivity to change – for this I used the standard deviations available on the coindesk quotes pages referenced in the question. I multiplied the gains by the standard deviations which had the effect of deweighting more stable currencies and increasing the potential of those which have demonstrated the potential for larger movements. The impact is slight and I haven’t developed much of a methodology for determining appropriate weighting, so the results are naturally weighted. This does lead to a swap in primary choice – Bitcoin currently leads with 34% of gains, however Cardano (with 32% of gains) has higher volatility and thus potential to overtake Bitcoin. When SD is factored in Cardano has 34% of the resulting proportion while Bitcoin has 31%,  Ethereum has 28%, and XRP has 7% (adjusting out rounding error). These are the proportions I use for my forecast.

My prediction is based on a few factors the largest being past data Bitcoin remains the most stable form of Cryptocurrency on the market and still controls the lions share of it even as competitors have arisen. Meaning large market upheaval or unexpected events are unlikely to affect it as much. Furthermore, bit coin is the easiest to access via kiosks even the store I work at has a kiosk specifically for Bitcoin. While other crypto currency has kiosks most are meant short short term investment and quick profits. Finally, with the new U.S Department of justice task force focused on crypto currency cyber crime it could make the smaller currencies have issues as they are used often in illegal activities. While Bitcoin is also used in these illegal transactions due to its stability it’s less likely to be effected by this. The overall issue with crypto currency is outside of Bitcoin it is very volatile so any of them could be the most profitable. Cardano on the other hand has shown exponential growth on the crypto market, but is fairly new so it is hard to judge it's market durability at this point. Overall though it has had a market increase of 1,714,52% increase over last year according to National World. According to Forbes this number is even higher since it was started in 2017, at around 10,500%. Bitcoin is the most established cryptocurrency and has a better price cap and volume compared with other CCs.  Bitcoin is also legal tender in El Salvador and may be used in different countries and stores/online sales sites soon.  However, because Bitcoin's prices are so high, currently $49,245, investors may place their money in CCs they can get a better return on for their money, and ETH and Cardano fall in this category.  ETH is more established and trusted, giving it an advantage over Cardano.  XRP appears to have much higher volatility (prices range from ~$.17 to $1.94 over the past year).  There is a discussion that XRP may be the CC of choice because ETH and Cardano are down ~15%, but it is total speculation.  If prices go up, it is only because the masses jump on media predictions and meme recommendations.

Bitcoin has shown consistently strong returns, confidence and positive responses.  Etherium has also shown strong returns and consumer confidence.  Ripple and Cardano are less well know with much more variable performance and less consistent positive consumer sentiment.

China saying it won't allow crypto currencies - that eliminates businesses and investors.  However, it removes a question mark from a significant government/investors who can influence the market, which increases stability (after previous partial bans).  Bitcoin options had an expiration of 01 Oct, that helped the value recover from losses earlier in September.  Based on the closeout date of this question, that gives Bitcoin a higher starting value leading off the final 60 days of the window.  Additionally, name recognition gives Bitcoin a significant advantage to remain the highest value when the window closes.  This is also a risk because if there is a drop, Bitcoin will suffer much more value loss than the other lesser known options.  However, with instability in the markets due to inflation concerns, Evergrande bankruptcy/bailout consequences, I do no suspect crypto "market shares" will be shaken up within these "competitors.

Judging from the CoinDesk projections of returns on investments, the performance of Cardano overall has been consistently better with a 1year return of 2306.86% far exceeding the other three cryptocurrencies. As well, looking at the daily performance charts, Cardano has been the least volatile over the period from 27 May 2021 to present. In addition, looking at the monthly average differential for each of the four cryptocurrencies, Cardano performs better overall increasing value by about 6.7% each month on average. Bitcoin, though at higher overall value, has only increased its value by about 2.5% each month on average with Etherium at negative rates and XRP just about breaking even. Given that the end of the forecast period is less than two months away, these trends are likely to generally continue.

According to CoinDesk, the second quarter of 2021 was characterized by price retracing in most crypto assets. 
The only assets that were in the green for 2021 Q2 were XRP, ADA and ETH, the native cryptocurrencies of the XRP Ledger, Cardano and Ethereum blockchains, which have continued their upward march returning 22%, 19% and 16%, respectively as reported by CoinDesk. Despite ending the quarter at a loss, BTC and ETH hit new all-time price highs earlier in the season. For bitcoin, 20% drops are common on the way to new all-time highs according to CoinDesk.
However, Some analysts characterize the recent upside move in cryptocurrencies as an oversold bounce. Technically, that occurs when prices become stretched to the downside, which encourages short sellers to exit their positions. Still, several risks remain that could limit further upside. One area of concern is the effort by U.S. and European authorities to enact stricter measures for users to exchange crypto for fiat currencies. This will be an ongoing development.
Based on the charts, I calculated that as of October 1, 2021 Cardano was the best performer with a 6 month return of 86.39%, followed by XRP at 77.76%. For the long term, Bitcoin and Ethereum have the most name recognition and the least speculative. My top 3 in this forecast are Bitcoin, Ethereum and Cardano, with Cardano outpacing in the short haul. @SEC.gov reports that Ripple is involved in litigation concerning an SEC complaint, filed in federal district court in Manhattan that charges Ripple defendants with violating the registration provisions of the Securities Act of 1933, and seeks injunctive relief, disgorgement with prejudgment interest, and civil penalties. This litigation if successful could have long term effects on Ripple's viability.

In first four months of question the performance was as follows - Bitcoin up 20% Cardano up 28% Etherium up 19% XRP up 8%.  Continuous volatility - who thinks these are good ideas need to think again....

Bitcoin:
-	$29B of trades per day
-	Supply limited (21M cap)
-	Catalyst coming between now and November: taproot protocol. This is the first upgrade in four years.  Ethereum:
-	Increasing in demand with $341M transactions per day
-	Is the choice for peer-to-peer networks
-	Moving to proof-of-stake protocol to reduce energy usage. This transition will not be a catalyst between now and the end of November. This transition may also come with some challenges; however, I don’t see these weighing on the stock in the short term.
-	Supply is unlimited but has an annual max of 18M. Cardano
-	Consumers are attracted to the smart contract function that is incorporated in its blockchain. However, it only has 150 dApps compared to Ethereum’s ~2,850
-	Lower network fees using proof-of-stake protocol 
-	Extremely energy efficient with proof-of-stake in comparison to Bitcoin and Ethereum 
-	Risky investment. Currently lacks backing from large clients/businesses. 
-	Supply limited to 45M Ripple
-	Low fees
-	Lacking large institutional cash flow. Ripple is trying to compete in the banking environment, but large banks utilize SWIFT instead of Ripple. 
-	There is a lawsuit weighing on Ripple (not helping the trust situation).  In the short-term, Cardano will outperform Ethereum and Bitcoin unless market risks elevate, forcing investors to less risk crypto like Bitcoin and Ethereum (China woes, significant market pullback [more than 6%], etc.). If the market becomes risk-off dominant, Bitcoin will outperform the other three due to being the least speculative. 
Cardano is showing investors promise as it is the best of both worlds between Bitcoin and Ethereum (supply limited, co-founder of Ethereum the inventor, energy-conscious, proof-of-stake protocol, and smart contracts). Based on market conditions, Cardano will outperform the other three. The close challenger will be Ethereum. Ripple is not a contender.

Long-term, XRP is done, based on the fact that it's not truly decentralized and its parent company is in the crosshairs of the SEC (which wants to make an example out of any bad actor and XRP is the only option that has a company behind it). Yet, I give it a non-zero chance of outperforming in the time frame based on the possibility of news of settlement or price manipulation or other vagaries of the markets. BTC has limited upside b/c any one coin can't dominate the total marketcap of cryptos going forward. I don't think it will go much higher than $100K in any event by the deadline. ETH and ADA on the other hand, by virtue of their relatively small (compared to BTC) market caps have the greatest upside and volatility, both of which make them favorites. From a fundamental technology standpoint, PoS (ETH and ADA) will win and PoW (BTC) will go away in the long run.  ETH is not yet PoS and ADA is, which could favor either of these depending on the timing of ETH conversion hitting its milestones. This report/prediction on ETH suggests it should be the favorite: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1bECqgijhgjdS782AB620gFjK5qx-vA99/view Yet there's a decent chance ETH conversion has delays, or worse has technical snafus and security issues, in which case I think ADA will outperform and take up demand that was aimed for ETH.

Bitcoin is most established of the 4. Has first mover advantage and is designed to benefit greatly from network effects. Has positive momentum recently from:
- Musk announcing Tesla would accept it for payments again once significant share of mining is done with clean energy. [1]
- El Salvador passing a law to make it legal tender in the country. This is experimental and has implementation questions, and it could be reversed. But several other countries are considering a similar move, and there is a competitive dynamic to early adoption. [2] I give it 70% odds that at least 1 country will still have a legal tender law or similar official support for Bitcoin by November.
- Institutional investment in Bitcoin is now a reality. [3] Ethereum is also established and benefitting from network effects. It has a distinct niche from Bitcoin so they are not in direct competition. Ethereum is leading in the cryptocurrency-computing and smart contract platform area and it will take major setbacks for ETH plus major wins for newer competitors to catch up.  I know much less about Ada and XRP. But they face a tough challenge to outperform BTC or ETH and would need to be really innovative. Unless they are in totally orthogonal/non-competitive areas to those 2 leading cryptocurrencies. "Perform best" is a very loaded term in the current crypto environment. As alternative currencies still vie for acceptability, Bitcoin remains in the "lead," but it's still not clear at this point whether this is a race to the top or one to the bottom. Add lots of noise/technical/meme trading, and it is a virtual certainty that the "prices" of all of these crypto currencies on 11/29 (whatever they may be) will me more or less meaningless. Oh well, here goes nothing!

One key factor to keep in mind is that when Bitcoin moves, "alt-coins" generally move in the same direction but with higher % magnitude. As a result, if Bitcoin makes another leg down, ETH, ADA, and XRP are likely to move down harder. The same applies to the opposite direction. With this in mind, my forecast is going to based on where I believe Bitcoin moves within the next ~6 months, and consequently the entire crypto market. Since Bitcoin's inception, its price has tended to follow a 4-year cycle containing a 1-year bull market resulting in a blow-off top followed by 3-year bear market. This 4-year halving cycle appears to be centered around the Bitcoin mining reward "halving events", which creates a supply shock and kicks-off the bull market. With this foundation, we can look towards historical patterns in the metrics derived from the blockchain. Looking at the on-chain metrics at the time Bitcoin topped in 2013 and 2017, we can see that the metrics looked very similar. When this is compared to the on-chain metrics at this most recent "top", the picture looks completely different and the metrics point towards Bitcoin being half-way through its current bull market. Based on the number of days after last Bitcoin halving event and these on-chain metrics, I slightly lean towards that the Bitcoin is still half way through its bull market. With this in mind, I forecast there being a 70% chance that the crypto market moves higher from here and a 30% chance it moves lower. In the case that the crypto market moves higher, as mentioned before "alt-coins" make higher % magnitude moves in comparison to Bitcoin. Based on ETH and ADA's large future potential and multitude of use-cases, these are likely to outperform XRP. Ripple likely has a rough future ahead of it due to its lack of use-case and uphill regulatory battles, most notably with the SEC. However, due to XRP having a lower market cap than ETH and ADA, and the tendency of lower market cap coins' ability to move with higher % magnitude, XRP has a non-zero chance to outperform ETH and ADA. I estimate this being a 1/7 chance. In terms of ETH vs ADA, both of these projects have bright futures and events ahead, and it is difficult for me to distinguish which will outperform the other. In the case that the crypto market moves lower, Bitcoin should hold up the best relative to the other coins. This is what has happened historically but I would also like to refer to the "Bitcoin dominance" chart (Bitcoin dominance refers what % of the total crypto market cap is Bitcoin). Looking at the 2017 bull-market, Bitcoin dominance had a tough time dropping below the 35-40% area. As of today, Bitcoin dominance appears to be bouncing off of this 40% area, which indicates we may see more Bitcoin strength in the short-term (2-4 months). If the market were to crash, this would support the idea that Bitcoin will hold up the strongest relative to ETH, ADA, and XRP.

My predictions are based on 
1) will the entire crypto market go up or down during the stated time range 
2) How volatile are the assets relative to each other?
3) Is there possibility of event-driven price fluctuations for these cryptocurrencies? The first question is very dependent on many external factors, such as whether inflation rates will rise, institutional investors will become market participants as a way to hedge against their traditional investments, or whether there could be another crypto crash just like how there was one in 2018. This is hard to predict and I would say that it is 50-50. The second question is important to consider as these cryptocurrencies have different volatility profiles and can behave differently whether the market is up or down. In the case that the entire crypto market is up, the crypto with the highest "beta" (relative to BTC) should theoretically go up the most and perform the best. In the other hand, if the crypto market goes down, then the reverse should happen and the least volatile cryptocurrency should perform the best. Typically, the larger the market cap of a cryptocurrency, the less subject it is to volatile swings. The ordering by market cap for the listed coins are BTC, ETH, ADA, and XRP, with a respective market cap of (612B, 282B, 47B, 38B) at the time of writing. Based on these observations, it would seem as if either BTC or XRP would perform the best (BTC in a bear market as it would see the least in declines, conversely XRP in a bull market as it would see the most in gains) The final question to consider is whether or not there will be event-driven price fluctuations during the time period. One of the biggest changes will be happening to the Ethereum blockchain in the form of the London Hard Fork, as ETH developers are planning to switch to ETH 2.0. This will come in the form of a change in the ETH transaction fee (gas) system which will in turn cause deflationary mechanisms to the amount of ETH that is circulating as new transactions will have a fixed fee, thus lowering the profits of ETH miners. As an ETH miner myself, I am actually quite bullish on the London Fork, as it will increase the scarcity of ETH as the supply will grow less rapidly and therefore drive up the price.
